DOC.HEAD: Report That Bids Are Low Causes Hilton Stock Price To Fall
DOC.TEXT: Hilton Hotels Corp. stock plunged Wednesday on a report that offers for the hotel-casino company are in the $90 range instead of the $120 some analysts had believed Hilton would fetch. Hilton, which was put up for sale last summer after the settlement of a dispute over the estate of founder Conrad Hilton, fell $6.87{ to close at $82.87{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange. The Wall Street Journal reported that JMB Realty Corp., a Chicago-based pension fund manager, had offered about $90 a share for Hilton, which would bring the total offer to $4.3 billion. Hilton general counsel William Lebo declined to comment on the report. Another of the bidders for Hilton is Miller-Klutznick-Davis-Gray Co., billionaire investor Marvin Davis' Denver-based real estate vehicle. The Journal reported that Miller-Klutznick was bidding about the market price for the stock, which was about $90 before the Journal report Wednesday. Calls to Miller-Klutznick and JMB were not returned. Hilton stock was trading at $63 per share when Conrad Hilton's son, Barron Hilton, settled the estate dispute in May. In August, Hilton stock soared to $112 a share on reports that the company would consider at least two formal buyout bids. At that time, some analysts were estimating that shareholders were likely to get $120 per share if Hilton was sold and possibly as much as $140. But the collapse of the junk bond market and fears of a recession have made it much harder to complete takeovers recently, and the stock price has gradually fallen as no deal was announced. Hilton had its best year ever in 1987, when profits rose 43 percent and earnings were $5.59 per share. Earnings fell to $2.72 per share last year and have remained relatively flat this year, rising 2 percent in the July-September quarter to $28.1 million, or 57 cents a share.
